Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group

August 1, 2018 Paul Moon Counter Adversary Operations 


In an indictment unsealed by the U.S. Department of Justice (DoJ) on Aug. 1, 2018, three Ukrainian nationals have been charged with conspiracy, wire fraud, computer hacking, access device fraud and aggravated identity theft.
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text: Dmytro Fedorov, 44, Fedir Hladyr, 33, and Andrii Kopakov, 30, are suspected to be key members within CARBON SPIDER’s point of sale (POS) subgroup.
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text: The arrests took place between January and June 2018, and coincided with a slowdown in CARBON SPIDER activity.
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text: The DoJ announcement also details the group’s use of a front company, named Combi Security, to recruit developers and intrusion specialists for its operations.
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text: Given that other members of this subgroup remain at large, it is likely that the tactics, techniques and procedures (TTPs) may change but activity will continue.
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text: CARBON SPIDER, more widely known as the Carbanak group, is a long-standing criminal enterprise responsible for compromising banks to transfer funds to mule accounts, performing ATM jackpotting attacks, and conducting mass compromise of debit and credit cards from POS terminals in large enterprises.
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text: They have been active in some form since at least 2013.
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text: During that time, the group has focused on the banking, financial, media, technology, hospitality, and food and beverage verticals, using targeted campaigns to reach their objectives.
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text:
Untangling the CARBON SPIDER Web
The structure of CARBON SPIDER is very complex and was initially suspected to be a single group, based on their use of several custom tools and specific TTPs.
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text: However, further research into the structure indicates that there are several clusters of activity likely made up of subgroups serving different missions, potentially with access to a shared development environment and pool of resources.
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text: A complex structure such as this is difficult to manage and speaks to the sophistication of the actor.
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text: This blog aims to examine CARBON SPIDER over time and attempts to describe their changing relationship within the eCrime ecosystem.
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text:
Custom Tools
CARBON SPIDER has leveraged many custom tools since it began activity in 2013, including its primary implant Sekur (a.k.a. Anunak).
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text:
These include the following:
Sekur



Name
Sekur


Aliases
Anunak and Carbanak RAT


First Seen
February 2014 (based on compile time)


Last Seen
November 2017 (based on compile time)
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text:
Purpose
Primary remote access toolkit (RAT) for monitoring victim systems of interest


Type
Microsoft Windows executable


Example Hash
f70cef297efe9ec0abea369b3c1235f14220a6165b48f6e8aa054296078122c8


Falcon EPP protection
Machine learning: Cloud-based, on-sensor indicators of attack(IOAs): Suspicious activity


MITRE ATT&CK™ technique analysis from Hybrid Analysis




 
Sekur has been CARBON SPIDER’s primary tool for several years, although usage over the last year appears to have declined.
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text: It contains all the functionality you would expect from a RAT, allowing the adversary to execute commands, manage the file system, manage processes, and collect data.
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text: In addition, it can record videos of victim sessions, log keystrokes, enable remote desktop, or install Ammyy Admin or VNC modules.
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text: From July 2014 on, samples were compiled with the capability to target Epicor POS systems and to collect credit card data.
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text:
Agent ORM



Name
Agent ORM


Aliases
Toshliph and DRIFTPIN


First Seen
June 2015 (based on compile time)
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text:
Last Seen
May 2016 (based on compile time)
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text:
Purpose
First-stage information collection and downloading next-stage payloads


Type
Microsoft Windows executable


Example Hash
36937e5e744873b3646c9d345e8cf50fb969029dc77525acfe63d5a9d28b73f2


Falcon EPP protection
Machine learning: Cloud-based, on-sensor IOAs:
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text:
Suspicious activity


MITRE ATT&CK™ technique analysis from Hybrid Analysis




 
Agent ORM began circulating alongside Sekur in campaigns throughout the second half of 2015.
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text: The malware collects basic system information and is able to take screenshots of victim systems.
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text: It is used to download next-stage payloads when systems of interest are identified.
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text: It is strongly suspected that Agent ORM has been deprecated in favor of script-based first-stage implants (VB Flash, JS Flash, and Bateleur).
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text:
VB Flash



Name
VB Flash


Aliases
HALFBAKED


First Seen
September 2015 (based on observed distribution)


Last Seen
May 2017 (based on observed distribution)
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text:
Purpose
First-stage information collection and downloading next-stage payloads


Type
VBScript


Example Hash
a7a927bd44040817ae39e15aeb3f0b69ca943d4ce5b00d12eed6fae5b1c325d0


Falcon EPP protection
IOAs: Attacker methodology;
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text:
Suspicious activity



 
VB Flash was first observed being deployed alongside Agent ORM in September 2015.
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text: It is likely that this was developed as a replacement to Agent ORM and contained similar capabilities.
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text: The first observed instance of VB Flash included comments and was easy to analyze—later versions soon began to integrate multiple layers of obfuscation.
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text: Several versions of VB Flash were developed including ones that utilized Google Forms, Google Macros, and Google Spreadsheets together to make a command-and-control (C2) channel.
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text: This variant would POST victim data to a specified Google form, then make a request to a Google macro script, receiving an address for a Google Spreadsheet from which to request commands.
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text:
JS Flash



Name
JS Flash


Aliases
JavaScript variant of HALFBAKED


First Seen
May 2017 (based on observed distribution)


Last Seen
November 2017 (based on observed distribution)
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text:
Purpose
First-stage information collection and downloading next-stage payloads


Type
JavaScript


Example Hash
ffebcc4d2e851baecd89bf11103e3c9de86f428fdeaf0f8b33d9ea6f5ef56685


Falcon EPP protection
IOAs: Attacker methodology; Suspicious activity



 
JS Flash capabilities closely resemble those of VB Flash and leverage interesting techniques in deployment via batch scripts embedded as OLE objects in malicious documents.
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text: Many iterations of JS Flash were observed being tested before deployment, containing minor changes to obfuscation and more complex additions, such as the ability to download TinyMet (a cutdown of the Metasploit Meterpreter payload).
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text: PowerShell was also used heavily for the execution of commands and arbitrary script execution.
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text: No JS Flash samples were observed being deployed after November 2017.
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text:
Bateleur



Name
Bateleur


Aliases
N/A


First Seen
June 2017 (based on observed distribution)


Last Seen
April 2018 (based on observed distribution)
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text:
Purpose
First-stage information collection and downloading next-stage payloads


Type
JavaScript


Example Hash
da70df51aa80414fcba9bf7322e44e8ea5ed6a3725f342cd05c733376c6f2121


Falcon
EPP protection
IOAs: Malicious document; Establishing persistence.
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text: MITRE
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text:
ATT&CK™ technique analysis from Hybrid Analysis




 
Bateleur deployments began not long after JS Flash and were also written in JavaScript.
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text: Deployments were more infrequent and testing was not observed.
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text: It is likely that Bateleur was run in parallel as an alternative tool and eventually replaced JS Flash as CARBON SPIDER’s first stage tool of choice.
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text: Although much simpler in design than JS Flash, all executing out of a single script with more basic obfuscation, Bateleur has a wealth of capabilities—including the ability to download arbitrary scripts and executables, deploy TinyMet, execute commands via PowerShell, deploy a credential stealer, and collect victim system information such as screenshots.
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text:
Clusters of Activity
Based on the use of these tools, it is possible to group the CARBON SPIDER activity into several clusters.
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text: These clusters may represent different groups with a common tool supply chain, or isolated campaigns from the same group, using separate individuals to carry out attacks with a different focus.
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text: Point of Sale (POS)
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text:
Targeting



Target Region
Primarily U.S. and Western Europe


Target Sector
Enterprises that process many card transactions (in particular casinos, hotels, and restaurant chains)


Active From
At least mid 2015


Active To
Current



 
The POS cluster is the most prolific associated to the CARBON SPIDER actor and is also known as FIN7.
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text: This cluster has used all the custom tools described with VB Flash, JS Flash, and Bateleur that are unique to them.
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text: Over time, they have used targeted spear phishing emails to deploy malicious documents that initially used exploits; more recently, they have used macros and OLE embedded objects.
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text: The primary method of cash out for this group is the acquisition and sale of credit and debit card dumps from POS devices.
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text: Many of the stolen cards are sold as collectives on the eCrime marketplace, Joker’s Stash.
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text:
Targeting of Russian Financial Institutions



Target Region
Russia


Target Sector
Financial and banking


Active From
Late 2013


Active To
Early 2015
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text: This cluster can also be described as the original Carbanak group.
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text: It is suspected that they stole large sums of money using several cash out methods against Russian banks, at which point the group may have diverged.
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text: It is likely that they developed the primary CARBON SPIDER implant Sekur and were, at the point of being operational, probably the only users of it.
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text:
Targeting of Middle Eastern Financial Institutions



Target Region
Middle East and South Asia


Target Sector
Financial and banking


Active From
October 2014
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text:
Active To
Activity reported up to at least early 2016



 
Although the targeting profile is the same as the Russian banking cluster, the TTPs are very different.
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text: In particular, the use of tooling stands out from other clusters of CARBON SPIDER activity.
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text:
As with other clusters, the primary infection vector is targeted spear phishing emails that use exploits for a variety of vulnerabilities in Microsoft Office:

CVE-2015-2545
CVE-2014-4114
CVE-2015-1770
CVE-2015-1641

A custom .NET
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text: first stage payload is deployed that in some cases deploys Agent ORM or Sekur, but is also used to deploy NetWire.
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text: Instances of DarkComet and Morphine RAT use some custom .NET
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text: downloader servers as their C2.
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text: One possibility is that CARBON SPIDER outsourced deployment of their malware for this campaign.
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text: An alternative theory is that this is a seperate group also using CARBON SPIDER tools.
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text: Little is reported publicly about the successfulness of this cluster of activity, and no cash out methods are known.
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text:
Targeting of Eastern European Financial Institutions



Target Region
Ukraine and Eastern Europe


Target Sector
Likely financial and banking


Active From
Mid-2015


Active To
Last known activity in late 2015



 
The Eastern European banking cluster is based on a single campaign using a strategic web compromise of an Italian bank in Ukraine to deploy instances of Agent ORM to likely Ukrainian targets.
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text: It is likely that this cluster links to one of the other clusters of Sekur activity, possibly the unattributed activity discussed below.
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text: However, no follow-on actions have been observed past Agent ORM deployment.
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text:
Unattributed



Target Region
Where known (appears to be Ukraine)


Target Sector
Not known in most cases (one case focused on news and media organizations)
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text:
Active From
May 2015
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text:
Active To
At least January 2017
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text: The unattributed activity is based on a cluster of Sekur activity that runs in parallel with the POS cluster of activity, but does not exhibit the same TTPs (with differences in Sekur configuration, campaigns, and infrastructure selection).
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text: Many of these samples were submitted from Ukraine; additionally, one of them was deployed using a malicious document with a decoy that suggests Ukrainian news and media targeting.
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text: It is possible that this activity relates to the Eastern European bank cluster of Agent ORM activity; yet without further evidence of follow-on activity, it is not possible to determine this cluster’s action on objectives.
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text:
Timeline
Below is a timeline showing the activity of each of the five clusters of CARBON SPIDER activity:

The timeline shows that several of these clusters of activity started just after public reporting of the group (around mid-2015) and that the divergence in activity may have been the result of this exposure.
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text: It also highlights that CARBON SPIDER now likely operates multiple parallel missions focusing on different regions and sectors.
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text:
Links to Other Targeted eCrime Groups
Beyond the described clusters of CARBON SPIDER activity based around their custom tools, their are also interesting links to other tracked, targeted eCrime activity.
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text: This includes the group dubbed RATPAK SPIDER (also known as Buhtrap) that targets Russian and Ukrainian financial institutions, a group dubbed Odinaff targeting SWIFT systems particularly in Eastern Europe, and the group COBALT SPIDER (also known as Cobalt) that, again, specializes in targeting Russian banks.
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text:
RATPAK SPIDER
Operation Buhtrap had a similar target scope (Russian financial) to the first cluster of CARBON SPIDER activity.
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text: Although these have always been tracked as seperate groups, there is a technical link between payload deployments.
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text: A custom macro dropper that would encode the payload using VB Script notation, and contained the strings “After OnTime” and “FUCK AV,” was observed in only 19 unique samples across Crowdstrike sample stores.
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text: One of the payloads was an instance of Agent ORM used to targeted casinos; a second payload also used by CARBON SPIDER was an instance of Sekur.
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text: The other six unique payloads observed being deployed using this custom macro dropper were instances of the Nullsoft Scriptable Install System (NSIS) downloader attributed to the Buhtrap group.
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text: Initially, this led to tracking both threats as CARBON SPIDER.
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text: Although it now appears that Buhtrap is likely a separate entity, the use of this shared deployment mechanism — unique to these two groups — suggests a common supply chain or developer and a closer working relationship, especially given some similarities in target scope.
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text:
Odinaff
A SWIFT compromise was observed in mid-2016, targeting a Ukrainian bank that at the time was unattributed.
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text: Based on similar TTPs, it was hypothesised that this could be CARBON SPIDER activity; however, although common off-the-shelf tools (such as Meterpreter and Cobalt Strike) were used, the custom CARBON SPIDER arsenal was not present.
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text: Later, this group was reported in open source as Odinaff.
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text: In addition to similar TTPs, there appeared to be some infrastructure overlap with two IP addresses.
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text: One Odinaff C2 was also reported to be in previous use as a Sekur plugin server.
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text: A second IP was also reported to be used by CARBON SPIDER in a previous campaign.
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text: Again, this may just be a shared hosting provider, but the TTP similarity makes this infrastructure overlap more noteworthy.
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text:
COBALT SPIDER
The Cobalt group, tracked by CrowdStrike intelligence as COBALT SPIDER, bears many similarities in the targeting of banks to the Russian cluster of CARBON SPIDER activity.
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text: Both groups also use Cobalt Strike and several other pen-testing tools in their operations; nevertheless, the two groups appear to be distinct outside of this.
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text: On March 26, 2018, an announcement was made that a Russian citizen identified by authorities as “Denis K.” was arrested by the Spanish national police in Alicante, Spain.
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text: He was reportedly involved in early CARBON SPIDER targeting of Russian banks and is suspected of being one of the members of COBALT SPIDER.
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text: Although reports suggest that he may have been a leader of COBALT SPIDER, activity has continued from this group, suggesting his role was not a key one within this organization.
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text: This suggests a link between the two groups between 2013 and likely, 2015.
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text: This is around the time that the dominant focus for CARBON SPIDER became targeting the POS systems of Western enterprises.
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text: It is possible that at least one individual left CARBON SPIDER and either joined forces with or created COBALT SPIDER.
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text:
Summary
CARBON SPIDER is the pioneer of targeted eCrime activity with some of the largest publicly attributed success.
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text: Their level of sophistication across the clusters of activity makes them a key player in the eCrime ecosystem.
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text: Although there is not enough evidence to directly link CARBON SPIDER to other targeted criminal groups, it is assessed with high confidence (based on analysis of artifacts and infrastructure over time) that CARBON SPIDER shares resources with other notable criminal groups.
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text: There are two possible hypotheses as to how the clusters of CARBON SPIDER activity are linked.
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text: One theory is that they were originally one group that splintered into several with different focuses.
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text: Several of the splinter groups may have maintained access to their custom tools (e.g., Sekur), while others moved on to work with other actors (e.g., COBALT SPIDER).
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text: A second theory is that CARBON SPIDER operates as distinct groups with different focuses, but they report to a single management structure.
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text: Resources may be shared between the groups, but each has its own members.
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text: At this stage, the first theory appears to be the most likely.
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text: Based on recently observed tooling and operations, CARBON SPIDER appears to be focusing their efforts on the POS cluster of activity against the hospitality and restaurant sector, with no recently reported activity against banks.
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text: They also appear to be moving away from their custom tooling, with no Sekur samples compiled since November 2017 and fewer samples appearing in live operations.
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text: Going forward, it is likely that CARBON SPIDER will continue operations to target sectors that give the best financial return for their efforts.
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text: For the short term, this will likely mean a continued focus on POS systems and large enterprises that process them.
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text: It is possible that they may return to target banks, but this would likely be on a small scale with very focused operations.
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text: CARBON SPIDER will likely move completely away from their old custom toolset, either developing new tools or using commodity off-the-shelf packages to achieve their objectives.
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text: This is even more assured given the arrests of three members of the most prolific CARBON SPIDER subgroup.
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text: As CARBON SPIDER adversary groups retool and alter their TTPs CrowdStrike will continue to track this adversary leveraging CrowdStrike CrowdStrike Falcon® Intelligence capabilities to combine endpoint protection, automation and malware analysis to prevent CARBON SPIDER from breaching our customer networks.
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

text: To learn more about how to incorporate intelligence on threat actors like CARBON SPIDER into your security strategy, please visit the Falcon Intelligence product page.
source: Arrests Put New Focus on CARBON SPIDER Adversary Group.html

SpiderLabs Blog

New Carbanak / Anunak Attack Methodology

November 15, 2016

                
                
                
                
                
                  10 minutes read
                
              

                SpiderLabs Researcher
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text: In the last month Trustwave was engaged by multiple hospitality businesses for investigations by an unknown attacker or attackers.
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text: The modus operandi for all three investigations were very similar and appear to be a new Carbanak gang attack methodology, focused on the hospitality industry.
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text: Carbanak is a prolific crime group, well known for stealing over one billion dollars from banks in 2015 (*Kaspersky estimated loss) and more recently orchestrating an attack on the Oracle Micros POS support site that put over one million Point of Sale systems at risk.
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text: The current investigations are still underway but the known indicators of compromise in these new attacks will be presented below.
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text: At the time of investigation this malware was not correctly detected by any existing antivirus engines, and domains / IP's were not found in any commercial threat intelligence feeds.
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text: It is also interesting to note that just during the time that it took to write this blog, Carbanak returned to their victims with significantly upgraded malware.
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text: This demonstrates the speed and versatility of this threat group.
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text: We have included analysis for two separate versions of AdobeUpdateManagementTool.vbs in this report.
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text: (The malware used following the initial infection) Version two arrived only two weeks after we began investigating this new campaign.
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text: Attack Vector
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text: The attacks began via social engineering.
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text: An attacker called the customer contact line saying that they were unable to use the online reservation system and requested to send their information to the agent via email.
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text: The attacker stayed on the line until the agent opened the attachment contained in the email and hung up when his attack was confirmed successful.
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text: The email attachment was a malicious Word Document that contained an encoded .VBS script capable of stealing system information, desktop screenshots, and to download additional malware.
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text: A screenshot of the malicious Word document is shown below.
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text: The malicious VB Script will use macros to search for instances of Microsoft Word running on the system, if found, it will clear the existing text and replace it with the following text.
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text:
The victim system will then reach out to http://95.215.47.105 to retrieve additional malware called AdobeUpdateManagementTool.vbs.
AdobeUpdateManagementTool.vbs - Indicators of compromise:
File name: adobeupdatemanagementtool.vbs
SHA-1 8d7c90a699b4055e9c7db4571588c765c1cf2358 (Version 1)SHA-1 a91416185d2565ce991fc2c0dd9591c71fd1f627 (Version 2)

Creates folder:
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text:
%temp%\WindowsUpdate
Creates folder: %temp%\WindowsUpdate_\Dropebox<username>
Adds file to WindowsUpdate folder: vbs
Adds persistence mechanism to the CURRENT_USER registry hive in the CurrentVersion\Run and CurrentVersion\RunOnce keys to autostart AdobeUpdateManagementTool.
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text:
A scheduled task is created named SysChecks which calls the vbs
A service is created named 'ADOBEUPDTOOL' which calls the AdobeUpdateManagementTool.vbs
The malware drops a Shockwave Flash icon and disguises itself as such.
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text:
The malware contacts the following and may attempt to download doc:

http://revital-travel.com/cssSiteteTemplates
http://juste-travel.com/cssSiteteTemplates
http://park-travels.com

All domains resolve to the same IP address (192.99.14.211)


http://95.215.46.249
179.43.133.34
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text:
The malware may report to the following command and Control Servers, depending on the version used in the attack:

http://148.251.18.75
http://95.215.46.221
http://95.215.46.229
http://95.215.46.234
http://81.17.28.124



This malware was capable of stealing significant system and network information.
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text: It was also used to download several other reconnaissance tools to map out the network.
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text: Downloaded tools have included Nmap, FreeRDP, NCat, NPing, and others.
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text: Two files of significance, el32.exe and el64.exe, are privilege escalation exploits for 32 and 64 bit architectures.
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text:
Their hashes are as follows:

el32.exe SHA1: 83D0964F06E5F53D882F759E4933A6511730E07B
el64.exe SHA1: CF5B30E6ADA0D6EE7449D6BDE9986A35DF6F2986

This malware was primarily responsible for the reconnaissance stage of the attack.
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text: However, it also downloaded additional malware that enables the next stage of the attack and could execute powershell scripts on command.
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text:
Beaconing - AdobeUpdateManagementTool.vbs
We have seen slightly different data beaconing methodologies over the different attacks, but the general approach has remained the same.
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text: Beaconing messages are sent out to 179.43.133.34 via standard HTTP GET requests every 5 minutes.
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text: Using this simple methodology allows the beaconing to hide very well within standard corporate network traffic.
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text: The content of the GET request is encoded with Base64 and secondarily encrypted with RC4.
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text: Trustwave has written a specialized decoder for this traffic and it can be obtained upon request.
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text: The innocuous nature of this traffic allows it to be stealthy in a corporate network, however, its uniformity of structure also allows analysts to identify it relatively quickly as well.
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text: Security staff can identify beaconing traffic using the following technique.
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text: The network packet times of the GET requests originating from a compromised host occur almost exactly every 300 seconds (5 minutes).
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text: No web content is ever returned from the GET request except for code 200 OK, as shown below.
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text:
(**Please note that the name=value pairs have been snipped for confidentiality reasons):
GET /{random_param_name}.jsp?qqksq=MTgzLTIyIDhBIDkwI …IDNFIDYwIDZCIDU4IEJFIDZCIENFIDY3&kfb4mz=MTgzLTIyIDhBIDkwIEV … IDBGIDUyIDZDIDhF&xzn8=MTgzLTIyIDhBIDkwIEVGID … DUyIDZDIDhF HTTP/1.1Connection: Keep-AliveKeep-Alive: 300Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencodedAccept: */*User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Linux; U; Android 2.3.3; zh-tw; HTC Pyramid Build/GRI40) AppleWebKit/533.1 (KHTML, like Gecko) Version/4.0 Mobile Safari/533.1Charset: utf-8Host: 179.43.133.34HTTP/1.1 200 OKDate:
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text: Tue, 08 Nov 2016 20:12:05 GMTServer: Apache/2.2.22 (Debian)X-Powered-By: PHP/5.4.45-0+deb7u2Vary: Accept-EncodingContent-Length: 0Keep-Alive: timeout=5, max=100Connection: Keep-AliveContent-Type: text/html
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text: The purpose of the GET request, with nothing coming back except the 200 code, is to "phone home" so the attacker knows the compromised system is available for further exploitation.
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text:
To locate these specific GET requests you can use the following regular expression as an initial filter:
grep -E "GET /[a-z]{1,4}[a-z0-9]{1,6}\.jsp\?" log.txt
Full analysis of this malware can be found later in this report.
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text: Second Stage – Carbanak / Anunak Malware:
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text:
Filename: bf.exeSHA1: 3d00602c98776e2ea5d64a78fc622c4ff08708e3
This malware executes a new iteration of svchost.exe and injects its malicious code into this running process.
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text: This hides the malware within the svchost.exe process.
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text: (*Warning- our analysis has shown that some antivirus firms incorrectly identify this file as ransomware.)
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text: It then drops a pseudo-randomly named configuration file into the %ProgramData%\Mozilla folder.
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text: This file's name is base64 encoded and based on the infected system's MAC code, so identifying it by name will be challenging.
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text: However, it does always have a .bin extension.
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text: Any recent file in this folder with a .bin extension may be suspect.
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text: It then searches Kaspersky antivirus processes and terminates them if running on the victim system.
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text:
For persistency, it registers itself as a service with the following details:
Service name: RpcSsSys (this name is random, may vary on different system)Path: "C:\Documents and Settings\All Users\Application Data\Mozilla\svchost.exe"Display name: Emote Procedure Call (RPC)
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text: It then proceeds to download kldconfig.exe, kldconfig.plug, and runmem.wi.exe.
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text: These tools are all well-known Carbanak malware and variations of them were used in the banking intrusions that made them famous in 2015.
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text: Additionally, the decrypted string references "anunak_config" which is the encrypted configuration file that it downloads from its control server.
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text: The Anunak crime group is generally believed to be synonymous with Carbanak.
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text: This malware is very multi-functional as it can enable remote desktop, steal local passwords, search user's email, target IFOBS banking systems (which Carbanak used so effectively in recent banking attacks), or install completely different remote desktop programs, such as VNC or AMMYY.
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text: Full details on this malware's functionality is included later in this report.
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text: Finally, this malware, like so many others, is designed to target credit card data by scraping memory on Point-of-Sale systems.
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text: This leaves little doubt as to its end goal on victim systems.
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text: The attacker uses social engineering to gain their foothold in the victim network, downloads reconnaissance tools to scan the network and move laterally into the card holder data environment, and then infects systems able to process card transactions.
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text:
Exfiltration – bf.exe
This malware provides the attacker remote command and control of the victim system via a multifunctional backdoor capability.
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text:
It communicates via an encrypted tunnel on port 443 with the following IP addresses:

5.45.179.173
92.215.45.94

These are also the destinations that stolen data will be exfiltrated to.
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text: This malware may steal credit card data, as well as screen captures, keylogger information, email addresses from the PST file, enable RDP or VNC sessions, or to obtain additional system information.
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text: All exfiltrated information is encrypted with base64+RC2 and sent via HTTP POST messages.
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text:
If you identify any of these IoC's on your network, you should contact a Trustwave account representative immediately, or reach out directly to the Trustwave SpiderLabs IR team at our 24-hour hotline:
24hr

text:
Summary
This file is written in VBScript.
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text: It can receive commands from the attacker to download and execute EXE files, VBScript, or Powershell script files.
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text:
Exfiltrated data is sent to the attacker's IP addresses through an HTTP POST tunnel
Analysis
Upon execution AdobeUpdateManagementTool.vbs will query the process in the infected system if it is already running, if an existing instance of the script is already running, it will quit, otherwise it will proceed.
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text:
It then attempts to read the following registry key:
HKEY_CURRENT_USER\System\CurrentControlSet\Control\Network\CC - Computer Count
The script then generates a unique identifier, using the following format:
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text: %md_id% - %l_ver% - %ptrtr% - %compCount%where:%md_id% - XORed Computer name and MAC Address.%l_ver% - hard coded in the malware script e.g. Dim HH5hjs54j69a: HH5hjs54j69a
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text: = "1"%ptrtr% - hard coded in the malware script e.g Dim HI0cvexizqw:
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text:
HI0cvexizqw = "2"%compCount% - value from the registry key: HKEY_CURRENT_USER\System\CurrentControlSet\Control\Network\CC, default value is the string "NO"
The malicious script checks if the following folder exists otherwise it creates it:
%AllUsersProfile% + "\Dropebox" + <username>for example in Windows 7 systemC:\ProgramData\DropeboxJoePC
The following files will be dropped under this Folder, these files are only created if required by the command sent by the attacker:
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text:
screenshot__.ps1 - a powershell script that takes screenshots of the active desktop
screenshot__.png - the screenshot image
exe__.exe - an executable file sent by the attacker
vb__.vbs - a VBscript sent by the attacker
ps1__.ps1 - a Powershell script sent by the attacker
insatller.vbs - updater script sent by the attacker

Every time this script is executed, it requests commands from the Attacker's control server using HTTP GET request.
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text: GET /{random_param_name}.jsp?pId==={unique
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text: ID %md_id%}<<$>>{MD5 hash of the current Date & Time} <- this is encrypted in RC4 with hardcoded key and Base64.
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text: The GET parameters may also be iterated up to 3 times.
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text:
User-agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Linux; U; Android 2.3.3; zh-tw; HTC Pyramid Build/GRI40) AppleWebKit/533.1 (KHTML, like Gecko) Version/4.0 Mobile Safari/533.1 Charset:utf-8 Connection: Keep-Alive Keep-Alive:300 Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded

id = the unique ID of the infected system (%md_id%)
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text:
bf.exe
File Info

Filename: bf.exe
Size: 267216

Summary
The file is a variant of Anunak/Carbanak malware.
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text: It provides functions from gathering information about the system to downloading and executing additional malware.
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text:
Analysis:
Malware Installation
This malware unpacks its main executable in memory and executes it.
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text: It then drops a config file in the %appdata%\Mozilla folder as well as copy of itself with the filename "svchost.exe".
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text: The config filename is a base64 string comprising of a unique string and the MAC address of the infected system.
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text: For example V14UDFcJZ1FfXQIIVA== to V14UDFcJZ1FfXQIIVA.bin.
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text: It then spawns a new svchost.exe process with the command: "C:\WINDOWS\system32\svchost.exe -k netsvcs" and then injects its code to that process.
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text: After process injection, the main malware executable terminates.
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text: In this example the Mutex named "V14UDFcJZ1FfXQIIVA" is then created.
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text:
For persistency, it registers itself as a service with the following details:
Service name: RpcSsSys (this name is random, may vary on different systems)Path: "C:\Documents and Settings\All Users\Application Data\Mozilla\svchost.exe"Display name: Emote Procedure Call (RPC)
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text:
Anti-reversing
The malware checks for the "isDebugged" flag in the PEB (Process Environment Block).
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text: It also checks for significant delay of code execution by utilizing the GetTickCount() function.
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text: Delay in code execution means the process is being debugged.
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text: Strings are heavily obfuscated to avoid static string analysis.
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text: The malware has a decoder table loaded in memory that is used for its lookup algorithm.
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text: All strings are deobfuscated on-the-fly.
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text:
decodertable = "\x00\x12\x1C\x13\x0A\x0D\x14\x07\x15\x0C\x16\x09\x05\x03\x17\x1D\x1A\x10\x1F \x0E\x08\x06\x11\x04\x1E\x19\x0B\x1B\x01\x02\x0F\x18\x20\x21\x42\x5E\x24\x25\x26\x4A\x28\x29\x6A\x6B \x2C\x2D\x53\x22\x30\x31\x7F\x4E\x34\x35\x4B\x5A\x38\x39\x7A\x7B\x3C\x3D\x43\x5F\x40\x41\x62\x63\x44 \x45\x46\x27\x48\x49\x47\x2B\x4C\x4D\x73\x4F\x50\x51\x52\x2E\x54\x55\x56\x57\x58\x59\x3A\x5B\x5C\x5D \x7E\x72\x60\x61\x2F\x23\x64\x65\x66\x2A\x68\x69\x67\x36\x6C\x6D\x33\x6F\x70\x71\x3F\x6E\x74\x75\x76 \x77\x78\x79\x37\x3B\x7C\x7D\x3E\x32\x00\x00\x00\x00\x00\x00\x00\x00\x00\x00\x00\x00\x00\x00\x00\x00"

An API Hashing technique is also utilized by the malware in order to hide relevant API functions it uses in its code.
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text: Rather than storing imported API names in the body, the malware author has pre-calculated the CRC hash of the API function.
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text: On runtime, all the malware does is to look-up the equivalent API name from its generated hash table.
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

avp.exe
avpui.exe

source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

The malware checks the system OS:

Windows RT

Windows XP SP2

If found, it attempts to exploit a vulnerability in "win32k.sys" identified as CVE-2013-3660 to escalate the privilege of the malware process.
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text: Obtaining the Proxy Settings
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text:
The malware gets the proxy setting from the Internet Explorer registry key:
HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Internet Settings\ProxyServer
It also gets the proxy setting stored in Mozilla's prefs.js file.
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text: The attacker however can push its own custom proxy settings to the malware.
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text:
Enabling Remote Desktop
The malware enables the Remote Desktop by starting the Termservice service.
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text: It also sets the service to auto-mode so that the service will start on Windows startup.
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text:
It also enables the following Terminal Server registry key:
HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\Terminal Server

fDenyTSConnection
EnableConcurrentSessions
AllowMultipleTSSession

POS Malware
Before the main POS routine, the malware searches data from the log file named "nsb.pos.client.log" and C:\NSB\Coalition\Log

It then enumerates the processes listed in a config file (klgconfig.plug) pulled from the control server.
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text: From here it scrapes the process memory heap for credit card data, specifically the Track 1.
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text: After collecting the card data, it creates a file where it stores the information.
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text:
This is the code snippet where it saves the data to an XML file:

Outlook Items
The malware also targets victim's email data by scrounging the victim's Outlook PST files for contact's email addresses, possibly to be used for further spear-phishing attacks from known individuals.
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text: Local Password Stealer
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text: The malware utilizes the open source project called Mimikatz and reused codes from this project to steal clear text local passwords from Lsass memory dump.
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text:
Plugins

ifobs.pl- the malware reused code from the Carperp ifobs module to target a banking application called iFOBS.
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text: This is a very popular banking platform in Russia and Eastern Europe and this malware can be used to compromise IFOBS banking systems.
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text:
When using this module, the malware hooks the following libraries:

{ "VistaDB_D7.bpl", "HProc2", 0xA9782FE7, "OpenDatabaseConnection" }, { "RtlData1.bpl", "HProc3", 0x1678D314, "TaskAfterSynchRun" }, { "vcl70.bpl", "HProc4", 0x8D55F8B4, "TCustomFormShow" }, { "vcl70.bpl", "HProc5", 0x3DF02899, "TCustomFormCloseQuery" }, { "RtlStore.bpl", "HProc6", 0xCF6CD66, "GlobalAppStorage" }, { "RtlData1.bpl", "HProc7", 0xAFD2F1E2, "FillDataToDBCache" },

ammyy.pl- this enables the malware to run AMMYY remote desktop control software
vnc.pl- this enables the malware to run a remote desktop VNC application

Backdoor Commands
The attacker can also send backdoor commands.
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text: In the malware code, a command hash table is used to compare commands (in readable strings) sent by the attacker, the hash of this command string is calculated by the malware.
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text: If the hash of the string matches any hash in the table, it executes the corresponding action.
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text: The image below is the command and it's corresponding hash (in green font)
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text:
Network
It connects to a hardcoded IP address: 5.45.179.173 or 95.215.45.94 through an encrypted tunnel at port 443.
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text:
Compiler/Artifacts
The following sections describe artifacts found in the file

legaltrademarks: Bobcats Kinsman

Conclusion
In many ways, this attack follows a very common series of events:

Social engineering / phishing used to gain initial network foothold
Cleverly disguised malware establishes remote control of victim system and downloads additional tools
Attacker conducts reconnaissance to scan network, expand foothold, and identify high-value targets
Payment card information and/or PII (personally identifiable information) is captured and exfiltated back to the attacker.
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text: However, the persistence, professionalism, and pervasiveness of this campaign is at a level rarely seen by Trustwave.
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text: The malware used is very multifaceted and still not caught by most (if any) antivirus engines.
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text: The social engineering is highly targeted, conducted via direct phone calls by threat actors with excellent English skills.
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text: The network reconnaissance and lateral movement is rapid and highly effective.
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text: Finally, the data exfiltration methodology is stealthy and efficient.
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text: Carbanak is one of the most sophisticated threat actors in the cybercrime realm today and this report details a very active campaign currently being leveraged against hospitality and restaurant industries (and probably others).
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

text: We encourage everyone to search their network for the IOC's described in this report and to contact Trustwave immediately if any are found.
source: New Carbanak _ Anunak Attack Methodology.html

source: The Great Bank Robbery_ the Carbanak APT _ Securelist.html

text: The story of Carbanak began when a bank from Ukraine asked us to help with a forensic investigation.
source: The Great Bank Robbery_ the Carbanak APT _ Securelist.html

text: Money was being mysteriously stolen from ATMs.
source: The Great Bank Robbery_ the Carbanak APT _ Securelist.html

text: Our initial thoughts tended towards the Tyupkin malware.
source: The Great Bank Robbery_ the Carbanak APT _ Securelist.html

text: However, upon investigating the hard disk of the ATM system we couldn’t find anything except a rather odd VPN configuration (the netmask was set to 172.0.0.0).
source: The Great Bank Robbery_ the Carbanak APT _ Securelist.html

text: At this time we regarded it as just another malware attack.
source: The Great Bank Robbery_ the Carbanak APT _ Securelist.html

text: Little did we know then that a few months later one of our colleagues would receive a call at 3 a.m. in the middle of the night.
source: The Great Bank Robbery_ the Carbanak APT _ Securelist.html

text: On the phone was an account manager, asking us to call a certain number as matter of urgency.
source: The Great Bank Robbery_ the Carbanak APT _ Securelist.html

text: The person at the end of the line was the CSO of a Russian bank.
source: The Great Bank Robbery_ the Carbanak APT _ Securelist.html

text: One of their systems was alerting that data was being sent from their Domain Controller to the People’s Republic of China.
source: The Great Bank Robbery_ the Carbanak APT _ Securelist.html

text: Up to 100 financial institutions have been hit.
source: The Great Bank Robbery_ the Carbanak APT _ Securelist.html

text:
Total financial losses could be as a high as $1bn#TheSAS2015#CarbanakTweet
When we arrived on site we were quickly able to find the malware on the system.
source: The Great Bank Robbery_ the Carbanak APT _ Securelist.html

text: We wrote a batch script that removed the malware from an infected PC, and ran this script on all the computers at the bank.
source: The Great Bank Robbery_ the Carbanak APT _ Securelist.html

text: This was done multiple times until we were sure that all the machines were clean.
source: The Great Bank Robbery_ the Carbanak APT _ Securelist.html

text: Of course, samples were saved and through them we encountered the Carbanak malware for the first time.
source: The Great Bank Robbery_ the Carbanak APT _ Securelist.html

text:
Modus Operandi
Further forensic analysis took us to the point of initial infection: a spear phishing e-mail with a CPL attachment; although in other cases Word documents exploiting known vulnerabilities were used.
source: The Great Bank Robbery_ the Carbanak APT _ Securelist.html

text: After executing the shellcode, a backdoor based on Carberp, is installed on the system.
source: The Great Bank Robbery_ the Carbanak APT _ Securelist.html

text: This backdoor is what we know today as Carbanak.
source: The Great Bank Robbery_ the Carbanak APT _ Securelist.html

text: It is designed for espionage, data exfiltration and remote control.
source: The Great Bank Robbery_ the Carbanak APT _ Securelist.html

text:
Each bank robbery took 2-4 months, from infecting the first computer to cashing the money out #TheSAS2015 #CarbanakTweet
Once the attackers are inside the victim´s network, they perform a manual reconnaissance, trying to compromise relevant computers (such as those of administrators’) and use lateral movement tools.
source: The Great Bank Robbery_ the Carbanak APT _ Securelist.html

text: In short, having gained access, they will jump through the network until they find their point of interest.
source: The Great Bank Robbery_ the Carbanak APT _ Securelist.html

text: What this point of interest is, varies according to the attack.
source: The Great Bank Robbery_ the Carbanak APT _ Securelist.html

text: What they all have in common, however, is that from this point it is possible to extract money from the infected entity.
source: The Great Bank Robbery_ the Carbanak APT _ Securelist.html

text: The gang behind Carbanak does not necessarily have prior knowledge of the inner workings of each bank targeted, since these vary per organisation.
source: The Great Bank Robbery_ the Carbanak APT _ Securelist.html

text: So in order to understand how a particular bank operates, infected computers were used to record videos that were then sent to the Command and Control servers.
source: The Great Bank Robbery_ the Carbanak APT _ Securelist.html

text: Even though the quality of the videos was relatively poor, they were still good enough for the attackers, armed also with the keylogged data for that particular machine to understand what the victim was doing.
source: The Great Bank Robbery_ the Carbanak APT _ Securelist.html

text: This provided them with the knowledge they needed to cash out the money.
source: The Great Bank Robbery_ the Carbanak APT _ Securelist.html

text:
Cash out procedures
During our investigation we found several ways of cashing out:
ATMs were instructed remotely to dispense cash without any interaction with the ATM itself, with the cash then collected by mules; the SWIFT network was used to transfer money out of the organisation and into criminals’ accounts; and databases with account information were altered so that fake accounts could be created with a relatively high balance, with mule services being used to collect the money.
source: The Great Bank Robbery_ the Carbanak APT _ Securelist.html

text:
Infections and losses
Since we started investigating this campaign we have worked very closely with the law enforcement agencies (LEAs) tracking the Carbanak group.
source: The Great Bank Robbery_ the Carbanak APT _ Securelist.html

text: As a result of this cooperation we know that up to 100 targets have been hit.
source: The Great Bank Robbery_ the Carbanak APT _ Securelist.html

text: When it comes to financial institutions, In at least half of the cases the criminals were able to extract money from the infected institution.
source: The Great Bank Robbery_ the Carbanak APT _ Securelist.html

text: Losses per bank range from $2.5 million to approximately $10 million.
source: The Great Bank Robbery_ the Carbanak APT _ Securelist.html

text: However, according to information provided by LEAs and the victims themselves, total financial losses could be as a high as $1 billion, making this by far the most successful criminal cyber campaign we have ever seen.
source: The Great Bank Robbery_ the Carbanak APT _ Securelist.html

text:
Losses from #Carbanak per bank range from $2.5 million to approximately $10 million #TheSAS2015Tweet
Our investigation began in Ukraine and then moved to Moscow, with most of the financial entities targeted by the group located in Eastern Europe.
source: The Great Bank Robbery_ the Carbanak APT _ Securelist.html

text: However thanks to KSN data and data obtained from the Command and Control servers, we know that Carbanak also targets victims in the USA, Germany and China.
source: The Great Bank Robbery_ the Carbanak APT _ Securelist.html

text: Now the group is expanding its operations to new areas.
source: The Great Bank Robbery_ the Carbanak APT _ Securelist.html

text: These include Malaysia, Nepal, Kuwait and several regions in Africa, among others.
source: The Great Bank Robbery_ the Carbanak APT _ Securelist.html

text: The group is still active, and we urge all financial organizations to carefully scan their networks for the presence of Carbanak.
source: The Great Bank Robbery_ the Carbanak APT _ Securelist.html

text: If detected, report the intrusion to law enforcement immediately.
source: The Great Bank Robbery_ the Carbanak APT _ Securelist.html

text: For a full description of the campaign, IOCs and list of infections please see our report.
source: The Great Bank Robbery_ the Carbanak APT _ Securelist.html

text: To check your network for Carbanak’s presence, you can also use the open IOC file available here.
source: The Great Bank Robbery_ the Carbanak APT _ Securelist.html

text:
FAQ
What is Carbanak?
source: The Great Bank Robbery_ the Carbanak APT _ Securelist.html

text: Carbanak is the name we use for an APT-style campaign targeting (but not limited to) financial institutions.
source: The Great Bank Robbery_ the Carbanak APT _ Securelist.html

text: The main difference with other APT attacks is that attackers do not see data but money as their primary target.
source: The Great Bank Robbery_ the Carbanak APT _ Securelist.html

text: We say APT-like, however the attack is not strictly speaking Advanced.
source: The Great Bank Robbery_ the Carbanak APT _ Securelist.html

text: Strictly speaking, the main feature defining the attackers is Persistence.
source: The Great Bank Robbery_ the Carbanak APT _ Securelist.html

text: We name the backdoor Carbanak since it is based on Carberp and the name of the configuration file is “anak.cfg”.
source: The Great Bank Robbery_ the Carbanak APT _ Securelist.html

text: What are the malicious purposes of this campaign?
source: The Great Bank Robbery_ the Carbanak APT _ Securelist.html

text: The attackers infiltrate the victim´s network looking for the critical system they can use for cashing money out.
source: The Great Bank Robbery_ the Carbanak APT _ Securelist.html

text: Once they have stolen a significant amount of money (from 2.5 to 10 MM USD per entity), they abandon the victim.
source: The Great Bank Robbery_ the Carbanak APT _ Securelist.html

text: Why do you think it is significant?
source: The Great Bank Robbery_ the Carbanak APT _ Securelist.html

text: Banking entities have always been a primary target for cybercriminals.
source: The Great Bank Robbery_ the Carbanak APT _ Securelist.html

text: However it was almost always through their customers.
source: The Great Bank Robbery_ the Carbanak APT _ Securelist.html

text: This time attackers are targeting financial entities directly in an unprecedented, determined, highly professional and coordinated attack, and using any means from the target to cash as much money out as possible, up to an apparently auto-imposed limit.
source: The Great Bank Robbery_ the Carbanak APT _ Securelist.html

text: Can you explain the timeline of the campaign?
source: The Great Bank Robbery_ the Carbanak APT _ Securelist.html

text: According to what we know, the first malicious samples were compiled in August, 2013 when the cybercriminals started to test the Carbanak malware.
source: The Great Bank Robbery_ the Carbanak APT _ Securelist.html

text: The first infections were detected in December, 2013.
source: The Great Bank Robbery_ the Carbanak APT _ Securelist.html

text: On average, each bank robbery took between two and four months, from infecting the first computer at the bank’s corporate network to cashing the money out.
source: The Great Bank Robbery_ the Carbanak APT _ Securelist.html

text: We believe that the gang was able to successfully steal from their first victims during the period of February-April 2014.
source: The Great Bank Robbery_ the Carbanak APT _ Securelist.html

text: The peak of infections was recorded in June 2014.
source: The Great Bank Robbery_ the Carbanak APT _ Securelist.html

text: Currently the campaign is still active.
source: The Great Bank Robbery_ the Carbanak APT _ Securelist.html

text: Why didn´t you make the details public until now?
source: The Great Bank Robbery_ the Carbanak APT _ Securelist.html

text: Since we started working on this campaign we have collaborated with the different LEAs involved in the investigation and helped them as much as possible.
source: The Great Bank Robbery_ the Carbanak APT _ Securelist.html

text: As it remains an open investigation, we were asked not to share any details until it was safe to do so.
source: The Great Bank Robbery_ the Carbanak APT _ Securelist.html

text: Have you reached victims and Computer Emergency Response Teams (CERTs) in those countries where you have detected the incidents?
source: The Great Bank Robbery_ the Carbanak APT _ Securelist.html

text: Yes, this investigation turned into a joint operation between Kaspersky Lab’s Global Research and Analysis Team and international organizations, national and regional law enforcement agencies and a number of Computer Emergency Response Teams (CERTs) worldwide.
source: The Great Bank Robbery_ the Carbanak APT _ Securelist.html

text: One of our main goals was to disseminate our knowledge of the campaign and IOCs among all detected and potential victims.
source: The Great Bank Robbery_ the Carbanak APT _ Securelist.html

text: We used national CERTs and LEAs as the distribution channel.
source: The Great Bank Robbery_ the Carbanak APT _ Securelist.html

text: How did you contribute to the investigation?
source: The Great Bank Robbery_ the Carbanak APT _ Securelist.html

text: We’re helping to assist in investigations and countermeasures that disrupt malware operations and cybercriminal activity.
source: The Great Bank Robbery_ the Carbanak APT _ Securelist.html

text: During the investigations we provide technical expertise such as analyzing infection vectors, malicious programs, supported Command & Control infrastructure and exploitation methods.
source: The Great Bank Robbery_ the Carbanak APT _ Securelist.html

text: How was the malware distributed?
source: The Great Bank Robbery_ the Carbanak APT _ Securelist.html

text: Attackers used spear phishing emails with malicious attachments against employees of the targeted financial institutions, in some cases sending them to their personal email addresses.
source: The Great Bank Robbery_ the Carbanak APT _ Securelist.html

text: We believe the attackers also used drive by download attacks, but this second assumption is still not 100% confirmed.
source: The Great Bank Robbery_ the Carbanak APT _ Securelist.html

text:
What is the potential impact for victims?
Based on what the attackers stole from victims, a new victim faces potential losses of up to 10 million $.
source: The Great Bank Robbery_ the Carbanak APT _ Securelist.html

text: However this figure is arbitrary based on what we know: nothing limits the potential loss once an institution is infected.
source: The Great Bank Robbery_ the Carbanak APT _ Securelist.html

text: Who are the victims?
source: The Great Bank Robbery_ the Carbanak APT _ Securelist.html

text: What is the scale of the attack?
source: The Great Bank Robbery_ the Carbanak APT _ Securelist.html

text: Victims are mainly institutions in the financial industry; however we have also found traces of infections in POS terminals and PR agencies.
source: The Great Bank Robbery_ the Carbanak APT _ Securelist.html

text: For a sense of the scale of the attack please see the different charts and maps we provide in our report.
source: The Great Bank Robbery_ the Carbanak APT _ Securelist.html

text: As with many malware campaigns there are a variety of companies/individuals analyzing the malware, resulting in requests to the Command and Control server.
source: The Great Bank Robbery_ the Carbanak APT _ Securelist.html

text: When we analyze those servers, all we see are the IPs and possibly some additional information.
source: The Great Bank Robbery_ the Carbanak APT _ Securelist.html

text: When this additional information is not present, and when the IP cannot be traced back to its owner, we mark it as an infection.
source: The Great Bank Robbery_ the Carbanak APT _ Securelist.html

text: Based on this approach our analysis concludes that Russia, the US, Germany and China are the most affected countries in number of traces of infection (IP addresses).
source: The Great Bank Robbery_ the Carbanak APT _ Securelist.html

text: How are corporate users protected against this type of attack?
source: The Great Bank Robbery_ the Carbanak APT _ Securelist.html

text: Does Kaspersky Lab protect their users?
source: The Great Bank Robbery_ the Carbanak APT _ Securelist.html

text: Yes, we detect Carbanak samples as Backdoor.Win32.Carbanak and Backdoor.
source: The Great Bank Robbery_ the Carbanak APT _ Securelist.html

text: Win32.CarbanakCmd.
source: The Great Bank Robbery_ the Carbanak APT _ Securelist.html

text: All Kaspersky Lab’s corporate products and solutions detect known Carbanak samples.
source: The Great Bank Robbery_ the Carbanak APT _ Securelist.html

text: To raise the level of protection, it is recommended to switch on Kaspersky’s Proactive Defense Module included in each modern product and solution.
source: The Great Bank Robbery_ the Carbanak APT _ Securelist.html

Carbanak Group uses Google for malware command-and-control







Google Malware 










Forcepoint Security Labs™ recently investigated a trojanized RTF document which we tied to the Carbank criminal gang.
source: Carbanak Group uses Google for malware command-and-control _ Forcepoint.html

text: The document contains an encoded Visual Basic Script (VBScript) typical of previous Carbanak malware.
source: Carbanak Group uses Google for malware command-and-control _ Forcepoint.html

text: Recent samples of the malware have now included the ability to use Google services for command-and-control (C&C) communication.
source: Carbanak Group uses Google for malware command-and-control _ Forcepoint.html

text: We have notified Google of the abuse and are working with them to share additional information.
source: Carbanak Group uses Google for malware command-and-control _ Forcepoint.html

text: Carbanak (also known as Anunak) are a group of financially motivated criminals first exposed in 2015.
source: Carbanak Group uses Google for malware command-and-control _ Forcepoint.html

text: The actors typically steal from financial institutions using targeted malware.
source: Carbanak Group uses Google for malware command-and-control _ Forcepoint.html

text: Recently a new Carbanak attack campaign dubbed "Digital Plagiarist" was exposed where the group used weaponized office documents hosted on mirrored domains, in order to distribute malware.
source: Carbanak Group uses Google for malware command-and-control _ Forcepoint.html

text:
Weaponized document
The RTF document we analyzed (SHA1 1ec48e5c0b88f4f850facc718bbdec9200e4bd2d) has an embedded OLE object which contains a VBScript file.
source: Carbanak Group uses Google for malware command-and-control _ Forcepoint.html

text: When the document is opened the targeted user is lured into double-clicking on the embedded OLE object which is disguised as an image:
source: Carbanak Group uses Google for malware command-and-control _ Forcepoint.html

text: Double clicking on the image results in a file open dialog for "unprotected.vbe".
source: Carbanak Group uses Google for malware command-and-control _ Forcepoint.html

text: If the user executes this file then the VBScript malware will begin to execute.
source: Carbanak Group uses Google for malware command-and-control _ Forcepoint.html

text:
Encoded VBScript malware
The VBScript malware inside the RTF document (SHA1 cd75662751c59951717b4704ea2cdb6fb7ec19bc) is an encoded VBScript file.
source: Carbanak Group uses Google for malware command-and-control _ Forcepoint.html

text: We decoded the script and found hallmarks typical of the Carbanak group's VBScript malware, however we also found the addition of a new "ggldr" script module.
source: Carbanak Group uses Google for malware command-and-control _ Forcepoint.html

text: The module is base64 encoded inside the main VBScript file along with various other VBScript modules used by the malware.
source: Carbanak Group uses Google for malware command-and-control _ Forcepoint.html

text: When we analyzed the script we noticed that it is capable of using Google services as a C&C channel.
source: Carbanak Group uses Google for malware command-and-control _ Forcepoint.html

text:
Abusing Google for C&C communication
The "ggldr" script will send and receive commands to and from Google Apps Script, Google Sheets, and Google Forms services.
source: Carbanak Group uses Google for malware command-and-control _ Forcepoint.html

text: For each infected user a unique Google Sheets spreadsheet is dynamically created in order to manage each victim.
source: Carbanak Group uses Google for malware command-and-control _ Forcepoint.html

text: The use of a legitimate third party service like this one gives the attacker the ability to hide in plain sight.
source: Carbanak Group uses Google for malware command-and-control _ Forcepoint.html

text: It is unlikely that these hosted Google services are blocked by default in an organization, so it is more likely that the attacker will establish a C&C channel successfully.
source: Carbanak Group uses Google for malware command-and-control _ Forcepoint.html

text: The C&C procedure is outlined in the diagram below.
source: Carbanak Group uses Google for malware command-and-control _ Forcepoint.html

text: Upon the first attempt to contact the hard-coded Google Apps Script URL with the user's unique infection ID, the C&C will state that no spreadsheet currently exists for the user.
source: Carbanak Group uses Google for malware command-and-control _ Forcepoint.html

text: The malware will then send two requests to another hard-coded Google Forms URL which will result in the creation of unique Google Sheets spreadsheet and Google Form IDs for the victim.
source: Carbanak Group uses Google for malware command-and-control _ Forcepoint.html

text:
The second time the Google Apps Script is requested, the C&C will return the unique Google Sheet and Google Form ID values:


The "entry" value is also a unique ID which is sent with each subsequent Google Forms C&C request.
source: Carbanak Group uses Google for malware command-and-control _ Forcepoint.html

text:
Protection statement
Forcepoint™ customers are protected against this threat via TRITON® ACE at the following stages of attack:
Stage 5 (Dropper File) -
source: Carbanak Group uses Google for malware command-and-control _ Forcepoint.html

text: The malware components are prevented from being downloaded and/or executed.
source: Carbanak Group uses Google for malware command-and-control _ Forcepoint.html

text: Stage 6 (Call Home) -
source: Carbanak Group uses Google for malware command-and-control _ Forcepoint.html

text: The HTTP-based Carbanak C&C traffic is blocked.
source: Carbanak Group uses Google for malware command-and-control _ Forcepoint.html

text:
Summary
The Carbanak actors continue to look for stealth techniques to evade detection.
source: Carbanak Group uses Google for malware command-and-control _ Forcepoint.html

text: Using Google as an independent C&C channel is likely to be more successful than using newly created domains or domains with no reputation.
source: Carbanak Group uses Google for malware command-and-control _ Forcepoint.html

text: Forcepoint will continue to monitor this group's activities and share data with trusted partners.
source: Carbanak Group uses Google for malware command-and-control _ Forcepoint.html
